author: By Yan Zhuang
title: A Polarized Australia Confronts ‘Trump Style Misinformation’
description: The reverberations from election conspiracy theories, until recently the domain of political fringes, could be acute, as witnessed by the United States and Brazil.
content: The ballots should, according to the official instructions, be marked with a “yes” or a “no.” A clear and legible “y” or “n” is also likely to be counted. So is a checkmark, for affirmative, but an “X” is considered too ambiguous by the authorities and does not count as a “no” vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Suspect in Killings at Colorado Supermarket Is Mentally Competent, Judge Says
description: The man is accused of murdering 10 people in Boulder, Colo., in 2021.
content: A judge ruled on Friday that the man charged with fatally shooting 10 people at a supermarket in Boulder, Colo., in 2021 is mentally competent to stand trial, court records show, a reversal of a prior ruling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Gaza Has Suffered Under 16-Year Blockade
description: Held in place by Israel and Egypt, the blockade restricts imports to the region and prevents most people from leaving.
content: For some Gazans, Saturday morning’s surprise Palestinian attack into southern Israel seemed a justified response to a 16-year Israeli blockade. Others worried that the coordinated attack would only add to Gaza’s misery as the tiny enclave braced for a large-scale response from Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Courtney Kocak
title: Restless in Minnesota
description: A teenager tries to break out of the usual routine before school starts up again.
content: I drove my big blue boat of an Oldsmobile Cutlass Ciera — a hand-me-down from Grandma Betty — along the winding road to Matt Erickson’s house in Lakefield, the town next to Jackson, where I lived and couldn’t wait to leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aubrey Nolan
title: The Hidden Places Where You Find Your People
description: An artist reflects on the pockets of community New Yorkers carve out in a city of millions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Family Sentenced for Selling Bleach as ‘Miracle’ Covid-19 Cure
description: Mark Grenon, 66, and three sons sold $1 million of an industrial bleach solution that they claimed to be a cure-all, prosecutors said.
content: A Florida man and three sons who used a business masquerading as a church to sell more than $1 million of a deadly bleach solution that they claimed was a “miracle” cure for Covid-19 and other diseases were each sentenced on Friday to several years in prison, federal prosecutors in Miami said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Yeats and Beckett, Guarding the Irish Coast
description: The Irish Navy’s small fleet of warships may be named for celebrated poets and playwrights, but its mission is anything but whimsical, as a record seizure of cocaine from a cargo ship showed.
content: Ireland is proud of its celebrated writers, particularly W.B. Yeats, the vaunted poet who grew up partly in Sligo, a rugged, rural West Coast county that treasures its enduring role as Yeats Country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Riley Mellen and Aaron Boxerman
title: Israel’s Military Says Hamas Has Taken Hostages
description: The issue of Israelis in captivity is a deeply emotional and explosive one in Israel, with the government having paid a high price in the past for the return of its citizens.
content: Hamas militants have taken Israeli soldiers and civilians as hostages, the Israeli military said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yaqoob Akbary, Najim Rahim, Christina Goldbaum and Safiullah Padshah
title: Earthquakes in Afghanistan Kill Nearly 200, Officials Say
description: Two 6.3-magnitude quakes were followed by several large aftershocks, devastating entire villages in the western part of the country.
content: Two 6.3-magnitude earthquakes killed nearly 200 people in western Afghanistan on Saturday, officials said, the second major quake to hit the country in less than two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Feeling Terrible After Your Covid Shot? Then It’s Probably Working.
description: Fever, chills and fatigue may all be signs of vigorous antibody production, a new study finds.
content: A new study has an encouraging message for Americans who shy away from Covid shots because of worries about side effects: The chills, fatigue, headache and malaise that can follow vaccination may be signs of a vigorous immune response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Hamas Attack Has Haunting Echoes of the 1973 Yom Kippur War
description: For many Israelis, Hamas’s surprise attack mirrors one carried out 50 years ago, setting off a 19-day war that traumatized the nation.
content: For Israelis, Saturday’s surprise assault from Gaza was a recurring nightmare, coming 50 years and a day after invading forces from Egypt and Syria caught Israel off-guard, setting off a 19-day war that has long traumatized the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Kornelis
title: Ann Patchett Isn’t Parting With WordPerfect
description: The best-selling novelist refuses to yield when it comes to writing software, but she’s had a bit of a change of heart on Barnes & Noble.
content: Ann Patchett’s new book is called “Tom Lake” for some of the same reasons her previous novel was called “The Dutch House”: She thought it was clear, memorable and would sell well in bookstores like the one she owns in Nashville. It’s the kind of calculation that may have helped both books become best-sellers but that Patchett once considered a concession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: Her Strange Blisters Wouldn’t Go Away. What Was It?
description: It started with a bout of dry, itchy skin. Soon everything hurt. A specialist found a way to find some relief.
content: The 49-year-old woman knew as soon as she got out of bed that something was very wrong. A quick survey of her body revealed the source: Sprinkled around her bellybutton were a half dozen blisters. They were small — the largest maybe the size of a pencil eraser — and painful. They looked like the kind of blister you might get on your heel after wearing a new pair of shoes. Except they were on her belly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: An Officer Is Charged With Murder. Colleagues Briefly Drop Their Guns.
description: In Britain, where guns are rare, armed police officers have set off a debate about the extraordinary power they hold, and the extraordinary risks they face.
content: When England’s prosecution service announced last month that a police officer would be charged with murder after fatally shooting an unarmed Black man in London, the news was met with relief by the dead man’s family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen to ‘This American Life’: Audience of One
description: We bring the movies to you.
content: We bring the movies to you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: From the Fringe to the Center of the G.O.P., Jordan Remains a Hard-Liner
description: Once a tormentor of the Republican Party’s speakers, the Ohio congressman and unapologetic right-wing pugilist has become a potential speaker himself.
content: As a co-founder of the conservative House Freedom Caucus, Representative Jim Jordan, Republican of Ohio, once antagonized his party’s leadership so mercilessly that former Speaker John A. Boehner, whom he helped chase from his position, branded him a “legislative terrorist.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: I Wish ____ Would Run
description: We asked readers which other candidates they would like to see in the presidential race.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: ‘Here We Go Again’: A Cabinet Minister on Facing Anti-Sikh Bias
description: Harjit Sajjan, the emergency preparedness minister, has faced threats of violence from other members of India’s large diaspora in Canada.
content: In the aftermath of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s assertion that “agents” of the Indian government were involved in the shooting death of a Sikh leader in British Columbia, my colleagues Norimitsu Onishi and Vjosa Isai looked into growing tensions within the Indian diaspora in Canada, ones that reflect divisions in India that have been fueled by Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Hindu nationalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
title: Here is what to know about the surprise attack on Israel.
description: Sirens sounded across southern and central Israel early Saturday as salvos of rockets hit Israeli cities and gunmen crossed the border from Gaza.
content: Fighting continued into the evening on Saturday in one of the broadest invasions of Israeli territory in 50 years, as Palestinian militants from Gaza fired another round of rockets at Israel’s central heartland, including Tel Aviv, and Israel worked to clear militants from Israeli towns and retaliated with huge strikes on Gazan cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: Harry Smith Was a Culture-Altering Shaman. Can the Whitney Contain Him?
description: A solo show takes on the legacy of the painter, folk musicologist, filmmaker, obsessive collector and underground legend. It also hints at what has been lost.
content: “Far-out” is an accurate, but inadequate, descriptor for the high-flying (and often plain high) cultural magus named Harry Smith (1923-91). And the label “polymath,” too, while true, falls short for this innovative painter-filmmaker-collagist-musicologist-designer-scholar-curator-collector/hoarder, whose very first and very strange (it could not be otherwise) institutional solo is at the Whitney Museum of American Art.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 7, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 7, 2023.
content: An article on Page 6 this weekend about a new musical inspired by the singer Alicia Keys’s life misspells the name of her skin care line. It is Keys Soulcare, not Key SoulCare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: No Longer Just ‘Goggles and a Suit’: Anthony Nesty on How Swimming Has Changed
description: The first Black head coach of a U.S. Olympic swimming team talks to us about diversity in the sport and coaching in the Instagram era.
content: Anthony Nesty has been breaking barriers in swimming for decades. In 1988, he became the first Black person to win an Olympic gold medal in swimming, representing Suriname in the 100-meter butterfly. Last month, he was named the men’s swimming coach for the United States for the 2024 Paris Games, making him the first Black head coach of a U.S. Olympic swimming team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: G.O.P. Candidates Use Attacks on Israel to Criticize Biden for His Iran Deal
description: Republicans renewed their opposition to President Biden’s decision to unfreeze $6 billion for humanitarian purposes as part of recent hostage release negotiations.
content: Republican presidential candidates seized on the Hamas attack on Israel Saturday to try to lay blame on President Biden, drawing a connection between the surprise assault and a recent hostage release deal between the United States and Iran, a longtime backer of the group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: After 128 Years in a Pennsylvania Funeral Home, a Beloved Mummy Is Buried
description: Stoneman Willie, as he is known, was a legend in Reading, where his remains were on display for generations. On Saturday, the city revealed his real name and gave him a proper send-off.
content: For 128 years, he has been known only as Stoneman Willie, a figure lying in an open coffin in a Reading, Pa., funeral home, leathery and as hardened as his nickname suggests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elle Pérez and Lindsay Crouse
title: These Women Could Make New York Champions Again
description: With nearly every other local sports team stumbling, the Liberty is at long last on the rise.
content: The Mets are out. The Yankees are out. The Jets’ new star Aaron Rodgers’s poor tormented Achilles’ tendon is out. The Giants lost their first game by a brutal 40-0. It can feel like a dark time to be invested in New York sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
title: ‘We Are at War,’ Netanyahu Says After Hamas Attacks Israel
description: Palestinian militants from Gaza launched an early-morning assault on southern Israel, invading towns and firing thousands of rockets. Israel retaliated with huge strikes on Gazan cities.
content: Israel battled on Saturday to repel one of the broadest invasions of its territory in 50 years after Palestinian militants from Gaza launched an early-morning assault on southern Israel, infiltrating 22 Israeli towns and army bases, kidnapping Israeli civilians and soldiers and firing thousands of rockets toward cities as far away as Jerusalem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni and Michael J. de la Merced
title: How Beyoncé and Taylor Swift Struck a New Kind of Movie Deal
description: A recent change in antitrust law made it easier for the singers to bypass big movie studios when seeking distribution for their concert films.
content: Just before Taylor Swift’s concert film, “Taylor Swift: The Eras Tour,” passed $100 million in global ticket presales this week, its distributor, AMC Entertainment, announced that it had struck a similar deal with Beyoncé for the singer’s Renaissance tour. Both projects follow tours that became cultural phenomena and pushed sales records, and the films are expected to be hits themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Michael Corkery
title: California’s New Senator Was a Labor Leader. Why Are Unions Upset With Her?
description: Laphonza Butler was part of Uber’s push to avoid having to classify its drivers as employees. Her new appointment has drawn ire from labor advocates.
content: In the summer of 2019, Uber, Lyft and other companies that use contract drivers faced a crisis in California. The State Legislature was poised to pass a law that would effectively require them to treat their drivers as employees, meaning the gig companies would have to pay drivers a minimum wage, cover their expenses and contribute to state unemployment — all significant new costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Tones of Voice
description: Sid Sivakumar presents a set of kaleidoscopic conundrums.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle and Vishakha Darbha
title: ‘This Is the Republicans’ Dumpster Fire — They Have to Deal With It’
description: What is the G.O.P. to do?
content: The House of Representatives has no speaker, another budget showdown looms and the Republican majority is in disarray. To break down what happened in Congress this week, the domestic politics correspondent Michelle Cottle spoke with Opinion Audio’s executive producer, Annie-Rose Strasser. They discuss this unprecedented event — and what it means for the future of the House Democrats, American politics and democracy at large. Hint: According to Cottle, it’s not good news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Congressional Term Limits Might Break Congress
description: And not for the better.
content: The recent death of the long-serving California senator Dianne Feinstein at age 90 has raised, once again, the issue of congressional term limits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Julie Bosman
title: As Wisconsin Supreme Court Takes Up Maps Case, Impeachment Threat Looms
description: Justice Janet Protasiewicz’s decision to participate in a case challenging state legislative district maps could spur Republicans to impeach her.
content: The liberal majority on the Wisconsin Supreme Court on Friday agreed to hear a case challenging the state’s Republican-drawn legislative districts, a decision that could spur impeachment proceedings against a newly elected justice, Janet Protasiewicz, who refused to recuse herself from the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Russia Hits Ukraine’s Ports for Second Day in a Row, Ukrainian Officials Say
description: The ports have been regularly struck with missiles and drones by Russian forces, in an attempt to squeeze the country’s vital grain trade with the outside world.
content: The Russian military carried out overnight missile strikes on the southern region of Odesa, Ukrainian officials said on Saturday, injuring four people and damaging port infrastructure as part of a broader effort to strangle the Ukrainian economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Get Wildly Enthusiastic
description: You’ll need a can-do spirit to navigate this themeless from Alex Vratsanos.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — There is a lot going on in this crossword, the first themeless puzzle from Alex Vratsanos for The New York Times since 2018. That grid from five years ago was memorable for its interesting geometry; the thrill today comes more from the clues and the entries. There’s great trivia — much of it ingeniously concealed — and a neat bit of letter play involving the last three letters of the alphabet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Guerrero and Katie Van Syckle
title: What Sarah Jessica Parker, Molly Ringwald and Spike Lee Wore to Parties This Week
description: The New York City Ballet and Carnegie Hall hosted galas and Spike Lee celebrated his new exhibit at the Brooklyn Museum.
content: There were embossed gowns with gold trains. Long gloves embroidered with pastel flowers. And dresses heavy enough to require a whole forearm to carry, as fashion and dance fans came together on Thursday at Lincoln Center for the New York City Ballet’s annual fall gala.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Peinado, Brent McDonald and Meg Felling
title: Migrants Chased and Snared in Razor Wire: A Rare Look at Texas’ Border Tactics
description: Videos reveal increasing militarization as Gov. Greg Abbott orders more troops and concertina wire to try to stop illegal border crossings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Ameera Harouda
title: Hospitals and Morgues in Gaza Are Crowded as People Seek Their Loved Ones
description: The Palestinian Health Ministry in Gaza said 198 Palestinians had been killed and 1,610 wounded.
content: The streets of Gaza City were mostly empty throughout Saturday as Israeli airstrikes hit the blockaded Gaza Strip, sending huge plumes of gray-and-black smoke into the sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Interested in an Electric Vehicle? Consider Buying Used.
description: The prices of used battery-powered models have fallen sharply, as the supply of cars and trucks has improved.
content: If you’re in the market for an electric vehicle, the time might be right to consider a used one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How the Extraordinary Became Normal in Catholicism
description: The battles in the Francis era are remarkable but repetitive.
content: The Francis era in Roman Catholicism is a good example of how the abnormal and even extraordinary can come to feel, with enough repetition, old hat and status quo. The wildness of the last decade is undeniable: the first papal resignation in centuries, the elevation of a new pope who began casting about for the means to alter Catholic teaching, the attempted rebellions by that pope’s own cardinals, the growing threats of schism from both the traditional and progressive wings of the church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: Six Accused of Murdering Ecuadorean Presidential Candidate Are Found Dead
description: The prison killings have added to the sense that the nation is in thrall to a narco-trafficking industry with ties to the government.
content: The six Colombian men accused of murdering an Ecuadorean presidential candidate were found dead in a prison in the port city of Guayaquil on Friday, Ecuador’s prison authority said in a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carla Dirlikov Canales
title: For the U.S. and China, It Starts With Listening
description: In tense times, we should use the arts to find common ground.
content: There is a phrase in China, “zhiyin” (知音), used to describe the person who knows you best. The first character means to “know” or “understand” and the second means “music.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: Teen Is Charged With Murder in Stabbing of 13-Year-Old on Staten Island Bus
description: The suspect, a 14-year-old boy, was in custody after the killing, which occurred during an argument that the police said might have been gang-related.
content: A 14-year-old boy has been charged with murder in the fatal stabbing of a 13-year-old on a city bus on Friday afternoon on Staten Island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and Raja Abdulrahim
title: ‘The Children Were Terrified.’ Fear Grips Israel and Gaza
description: As Hamas launched a surprise attack on southern Israel, Israelis huddled in shelters and Gazans flocked to supermarkets, fearing the Israeli military response.
content: Israeli citizens, barricaded in their homes in towns near the Gaza Strip, called into television stations as Palestinian gunmen crossed the border into Israel and invaded their communities on Saturday morning. The Israelis spoke in whispers as they pleaded desperately for help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden’s Hopes for the Middle East Imperiled by Eruption of Violence
description: The Hamas attack on Israel could narrow the chances for the president’s efforts to negotiate a new alignment in the region by normalizing relations between Saudi Arabia and Israel.
content: For months, the Biden administration has been pursuing an ambitious diplomatic project to design a new Middle East for a new era. But the old Middle East, it turns out, still has something to say about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen and Violette Franchi
title: In Provence, Winemakers Confront Climate Change
description: Centuries-old varieties are being altered by weather patterns, threatening the economics of businesses in one of the world’s most important regions.
content: “You can taste the climate change.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Will the Motion to Vacate Be Vacated?
description: Some Republicans are calling for the weapon that dethroned Kevin McCarthy to be weakened. But it is not that easy.
content: Just minutes after his historic ouster as speaker, Representative Kevin McCarthy offered some blunt advice to his successor: “Change the rule.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Here is a timeline of the clashes between Palestinian militants and Israel.
description: The relentless and deadly conflict has persisted for decades.
content: The scale and complexity of Saturday’s attacks by Hamas shocked leaders across the world, but they came after decades of a relentless and deadly conflict that has killed thousands of people, forced entire generations to grow up under occupation, or created constant anxiety of impending rocket fire or bombings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: When Did Cashing Savings Bonds Become So Impossible?
description: Citing potential fraud, banks are making it increasingly difficult to pay out savings bonds. An unlikely beneficiary is the federal government.
content: Hoping to cash in a paper savings bond that’s been lying around for a few decades? Set aside a lot of time for disappointment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Spy Thriller and a Prismatic Look at Light
description: Two books with nothing in common except for Molly Young’s enthusiasm, and possibly yours.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Days Before a Vote, Republicans Feud Over How to Choose a New Speaker
description: A quiet fight over the rules highlights the depth of G.O.P. divisions. It could set the stage for a bruising election to choose a successor to the party’s ousted speaker.
content: House Republicans, divided and demoralized after the ouster of their speaker this week, are now quietly feuding over how to elect a successor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: Newsom Vetoes Bill Banning Caste Discrimination
description: The bill had driven intense debate within the growing South Asian community in California.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom vetoed a bill that would have made California the first state in the country to expressly ban discrimination based on caste, stating that the measure was “unnecessary” because it was already covered by existing laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne and David E. Sanger
title: On Russian Nuclear Threat, Putin Lets Others Rattle the Saber
description: While Russian hard-liners voice provocative proposals about using nuclear weapons, Mr. Putin presents himself as a moderating force — while never really taking the threat off the table.
content: Russia’s hard-liners are rattling the nuclear saber vigorously these days, on television and in academic journals, arguing that an atomic blast — in Ukraine, in Europe, or maybe in a test over Siberia — is the only way to restore the West’s fear of Russian might.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Hamas’s Control of Gaza Must End Now
description: Peace can soon follow, as it did after the Yom Kippur war.
content: This column has been updated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: How S. Epatha Merkerson, Actor, Spends Her Sundays
description: Known for “Law & Order” and now starring in “Chicago Med,” the actor can be found most Sundays at home in her favorite place: a bedroom she converted into a quilting studio.
content: The actor S. Epatha Merkerson is perhaps best known for her 17 consecutive seasons as Lt. Anita van Buren on the “Law & Order” franchise. But she has held many stage, film and TV roles over her nearly 50-year career, ranging from “Pee-wee’s Playhouse” to “Lincoln” and “The Piano Lesson,” and has won an Emmy, a Golden Globe and several NAACP Image Awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: California, Land of the Car, Could Soon Have Speed Cameras
description: A bill to install cameras has landed on the governor’s desk at a moment when pedestrian deaths are spiking nationwide.
content: California likes to think of itself as a cutting-edge lab for policymaking, a place where laws get passed first and then copied around the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Some Israelis are flying home to fight.
description: Many
content: As Israelis living abroad woke up on Saturday morning to messages from their families and news alerts on their phones, some started booking flights back home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman
title: Israel’s defense failures may change strategy toward Hamas and Gaza.
description: The broad attack by Palestinian militants, which Hamas viewed as mostly successful, revealed some significant failures.
content: Hamas’s attack on Saturday took Israeli intelligence officials by surprise, particularly the methods the militants used to enter and leave Israel, according to a senior defense official familiar with the information collected about the group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: 13-Year-Old Boy Stabbed to Death on City Bus on Staten Island
description: The police said the teenager was killed during an argument on the bus that may have been gang-related.
content: A 13-year-old boy died after he was stabbed Friday afternoon on a city bus on Staten Island, and another teenager is suspected of killing him, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Cost of Inaction on Immigration
description: If Congress would stir itself out of dysfunction to enact sensible changes on immigration, the nation could reap the benefits.
content: It is difficult to find an issue that more exemplifies the dysfunction of American government today than immigration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: An Attack From Gaza and an Israeli Declaration of War. Now What?
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is being pressured to launch a full-scale invasion that Israeli leaders have been scrupulously avoiding since 2005.
content: Nearly 50 years to the day after the Yom Kippur war of 1973, Israel has again been taken by surprise by a sudden attack, a startling reminder that stability in the Middle East remains a bloody mirage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: Diving Into ‘The Exorcist: Believer’
description: We knew Ellen Burstyn would be back. But what else? A discussion of some of the spoiler moments in the new sequel to the 1973 horror classic.
content: The spooky season has arrived and among this year’s crop of horror franchise resurrections is “The Exorcist: Believer,” the first in a planned trilogy of sequels to William Friedkin’s 1973 classic “The Exorcist.” If you know anything about this revamped version, you’ll know it’s not just one little girl who’s hacked by Satan, but two. For everything else, keep on reading — meaning spoilers ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Nicole Scherzinger as Norma Desmond? Yes, There’s a Connection.
description: It’s been cathartic to “create art from places of torment,” the singer-actor said ahead of the opening of “Sunset Boulevard” in London.
content: Nicole Scherzinger was exhausted. It was a week since Jamie Lloyd’s new production of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Sunset Boulevard” had begun performances, and Scherzinger was playing the lead role of Norma Desmond — the forgotten star of the silent screen whose attempt at a comeback doesn’t end well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman, Julie Turkewitz and Juan Arredondo
title: On Latin America Trip, Adams’s Warning Meets Skepticism From Migrants
description: Mayor Eric Adams traveled to three countries to discourage migrants from coming to New York. At each stop, people said they were still determined to make the trek.
content: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City flew by helicopter on Saturday to the Caribbean coast of Colombia, where hundreds of thousands of desperate migrants enter the jungle passageway called the Darién Gap. It was the final stop on a four-day trip meant to send a message: Please do not come to New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Koba Ryckewaert
title: On This Nature Preserve, Farmers Are Welcome, if They Follow the Rules
description: Can Europe fight the effects of extreme weather while producing enough affordable food? A model combining conservation with agriculture may offer a solution.
content: With cows grazing in a vast meadow surrounded by wire fencing, and with farmers checking to see how their livestock were faring under a scorching sun, it looked like a classic pastoral scene set on what was surely land dedicated to agriculture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: Crispy Tostadas, Fluffy Cheddar Biscuits and Rich Chicken Mafe
description: The leaves are turning shades of gold, and so are these recipes.
content: We’ll get this out of the way: You absolutely don’t need to fry tortillas from scratch for Rick Martínez’s tostadas recipe. Topped with seasoned beans, crumbles of chorizo, cheese, lettuce, cilantro and salsa, any store-bought fried tortilla will taste delicious. But if you would like to fry your own, Rick has helpful tips on how to judge when your oil is ready and what to look for in a perfectly golden, crispy tostada. Our main point here is to make this recipe whichever way you want. You won’t be sorry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel and Hilary Swift
title: Two Families Got Fed Up With Their States’ Politics. So They Moved Out.
description: The Nobles of Iowa moved to blue Minnesota. The Huckinses of Oregon moved to red Missouri. Their separate journeys, five weeks apart, illustrate the fracturing of America.
content: Steve Huckins, a native of Oregon, was preparing to move across the country when he went on Facebook to post a goodbye letter of sorts to his home state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: A Curious Censorship Issue at the Guantánamo Court
description: A prisoner’s PTSD was discussed in open court, and was central to a ruling that he was unfit for trial. National security censors redacted it.
content: When a judge disqualified a prisoner last month from being part of the conspiracy case in the Sept. 11 attacks, the ruling was based on one finding: a mental health board’s diagnosis that the man, Ramzi bin al-Shibh, had post-traumatic stress disorder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Travis, Don’t Fumble Taylor!
description: Joe D. couldn’t handle Marilyn’s fame. Can Travis handle Taylor’s?
content: The blond glamour girl and the sports superstar were doomed from the start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Human Resources, for Plants
description: A cadre of creative types now cares for the hundreds of thousands of corporate plants in New York City, one leaf at a time.
content: Felipe Gallegos used to work in fashion, designing store displays for Abercrombie & Fitch and Uniqlo. Now he spends his days with plants, helping them thrive in office buildings across New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Fighting in Israel and Gaza, in Photos
description: A multipronged surprise attack by Palestinian militants put Israel and Gaza on a war footing. Here are images from the assault and its aftermath.
content: Israel and Gaza were on a war footing on Saturday after Palestinian militants launched one of the biggest attacks in years from the Gaza Strip, sending thousands of rockets into central and southern parts of the country as heavily armed gunmen crossed border fences into Israeli communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Migrant Crisis Tests New Yorkers Who Thought They Supported Immigration
description: As the city’s resources strain under the influx of thousands of migrants, New Yorkers are still resolutely in favor of welcoming newcomers. But for how long?
content: Carin Bail said she was walking with a friend in Queens this spring when they stopped to talk with a woman who was holding a baby and crying. The woman had just arrived at a nearby migrant shelter, she explained in Spanish, and her baby would not eat the food there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nuwer
title: The Quiet Reading Room That Gets Trippy After Dark
description: The curious origins of the Athenaeum, a library on a nondescript Midtown block that is devoted to the psychedelic experience.
content: Midtown Manhattan doesn’t usually come to mind when thinking about the epicenters of psychedelic culture. But just three blocks from Grand Central Terminal, tucked within the sprawl of advertising offices, finance firms and chain stores, a community center dedicated to consciousness-altering substances has taken root.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: There’s a Dangerous Dog in My Building. What Can I Do About It?
description: Laws about dangerous dogs are designed to protect you, but before you involve the authorities, your condo has a duty to protect its unit owners.
content: Q: There is a vicious dog in my Philadelphia condo building. The dog has attacked at least two building employees, leaving bite marks and drawing blood. It also lunged at a resident who was able to jump out of the way. Each time, the dog was leashed. The owners have been asked by the condo board to muzzle the dog, but it doesn’t wear one, and the condo board hasn’t imposed fines. I reported the situation to the police, to no avail. I’m concerned that someone may be mauled by this dog before long. What do you recommend?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Sheinbaum
title: With These Several Rings, I Thee Wed
description: Traveling? Completing manual labor? Mindful of safety? There are alternative rings for that.
content: Married people don’t always wear wedding bands or engagement rings — at least not their original ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Stengel
title: Press Gangs
description: Four recent books wrangle with threats to — and from — the American news media.
content: According to a recent poll, trust in the media to “fully, accurately and fairly” report the news is at an all-time low. And no wonder: A former president has tried ( often successfully) to make the term “fake news” synonymous with, well, news. This comes amid traditional media’s economic decline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Meet the Plant People
description: For some, tending to our humble home gardens, dreaming of lush green splendor, is a pastime. For others, it’s a calling.
content: My hometown has a gardening store so lavish, so over-the-top curated with weather-stained terra-cotta planters the size of vintners’ casks, crumbling concrete birdbaths rescued from Eden and a jungle’s worth of fronds and boughs and leaves that it is a destination. Out-of-towners come to gaze at its tableaux of mosses, hand-forged shears and fairy lights, to dine on seasonal produce at its in-house cafe. I think there might be an actual waterfall back by the table linens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans, Alexandra Berzon and Ken Bensinger
title: Mike Lindell’s Lawyers Say He Owes ‘Millions’ in Fees
description: The disclosure, made in a court filing this week, is a sign that the pillow magnate and leading supporter of the election denial movement is facing financial stress.
content: For nearly three years, the pillow entrepreneur Mike Lindell has been one of the leading financial supporters of the election denial movement, a tireless promoter of false claims that Donald J. Trump won the 2020 election and of efforts to change how Americans vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Vivian Nereim
title: The war could upend Biden’s diplomacy on Saudi-Israel normalization.
description: Many Sau
content: The startling clash between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, which threatens to become a regional conflict, jeopardizes the months-long effort by President Biden and his top aides to push Saudi Arabia to normalize relations with Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, Sept. 30-Oct. 6
description: If you’re not one for big hullabaloos, you might have missed this week’s toughest word.
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: This Bachelor Has Seniors Hooked
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 7, 2023.
content: “Love is blind, but marriage is an eye-opener.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tobias Grey
title: Giving a Voice to the London Readers Don’t Often Hear
description: While working on a new novel, “Mister, Mister,” the author Guy Gunaratne examined Britain’s political legacy, and underwent a deeply personal transformation.
content: Yahya Bas, the hero of Guy Gunaratne’s new novel, “Mister, Mister,” is a tricky character to pin down. Is he an idiot, poet, jihadist or all of these at once?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amil Niazi
title: A New Mother Finds Solace From the Patriarchy — in Sex Work
description: The heroine of Ainslie Hogarth’s “Normal Women” is so desperate to escape the confines of conventional, upper-middle-class womanhood that she turns to a yoga studio that looks a lot like a cult.
content: Can you return to the person you once were? Can any of us ever truly go home again? The Motherthing author Ainslie Hogarth’s second novel, “Normal Women,” roots around this trope of going back — to your old town and your old self — and how geography, psychology and maternity can alter your very identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Leatherby, Karen Yourish and Elena Shao
title: Mapping Air and Ground Attacks in Israel and Gaza
description: The New York Times is tracking airstrikes and ground fighting between Israelis and Palestinians.
content: The New York Times is tracking airstrikes and ground fighting between Israelis and Palestinians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis, Rebecca Lieberman and Crista Chapman
title: How the Costs of Car Ownership Add Up
description: Pandemic disruptions drove the expenses associated with owning a car through the roof, creating a financial burden that many drivers didn’t bargain for.
content: Pandemic disruptions drove the expenses associated with owning a car through the roof, creating a financial burden that many drivers didn’t bargain for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadja Popovich and Adam Pearce
title: It’s Not Your Imagination. Summers Are Getting Hotter.
description: As the planet has warmed, summer temperatures have shifted toward more extreme heat.
content: As the planet has warmed, summer temperatures have shifted toward more extreme heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Paik, Nailah Morgan and Ben Laffin
title: Israel ‘at War’ After Hamas Attacks
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel announced that his country was at war after Palestinian militants launched a large-scale attack, resulting in the reported deaths of hundreds on both sides.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel announced that his country was at war after Palestinian militants launched a large-scale attack, resulting in the reported deaths of hundreds on both sides.
source.name: The New York Times
